Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: The roster is tight today and the coordinator reminded everyone that each role starts as soon as the doors open.
Story: This morning, I woke up to the smell of incense and the sound of my grandmother humming an old song in the kitchen. Today is the anniversary of my great-grandfather’s passing, and my family expects me to help prepare the altar and join the prayers, just as we do every year. My mother reminded me last night, “It’s important to honor our traditions. Your presence means a lot.” But as I glanced at my phone, I saw a message from the volunteer coordinator: “Please remember, we need everyone here right at 9 a.m. sharp. We can’t start without you.” The shelter’s roster is tight today, and I know how much they rely on me. My heart pounded as I looked between the family altar and my volunteer uniform. I could feel the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, each one pulling me in a different direction. I wanted to be the devoted child my family hoped for, but I also didn’t want to let down the people who counted on me at the shelter. I stood frozen, torn between two worlds, unsure which door I would walk through.
